so we can begin work on your claim. We apologize for this inconvenience.

Covid related means that somehow COVID-19 impacted your employment, e.g. because of the pandemic employees were laid off, business shut down, sick leave denied/unpaid, etc.

This wage claim, if submitted without comfirmation, will not be finalized as a case until it is confirmed by the claimant. If no confirmation is received from the claimant within 60 days, the case will be closed.
Claimant Confirmation is pending on the claim. To upload the Claimant Confirmation document

A representative from the Garment Enforcement Unit of the Labor Commissioner’s Office will contact you within the next 14 days to discuss your claim in detail. Please click the Submit button to process your request.
Did your employer have more than one company name while you were employed?

The Labor Commissioner's Office will need confirmation by the claimant to receive a claim submitted on a claimant's behalf. We will send a text message or email to the claimant to confirm. If you prefer to submit a written and signed confirmation, check the check-box and upload file.
If known, please enter the CSLB license number. If unknown, please skip.

There are some things that are important for you to know about our use of that information:
If you are filling this claim for someone else, please respond with the information for the person making the wage claim;
We will NEVER use the demographic information in processing a wage claim;
The demographic information will NOT be visible to, or shared with, those who process the claim;
Demographic information will only be reported in the aggregate and will NEVER be reported as to a particular person or claim
Non-Hispanic or Latino: If you identify with more than one race that is Non-Hispanic or Latino, select Multiple Races.
More than one Asian ethnicity: If you identify with more than one Asian ethnicity, select Multiple Asian.
More than one Pacific Islander ethnicity: If you identify with more than one Pacific Islander ethnicity, select Multiple Pacific Islander.
The following are demographic questions that assist us in our enforcement and outreach. The questions are voluntary but any response you can give us is helpful.

Is this employer still in business?

example: paycheck could not be cashed because the account did not have sufficient funds.

"Overtime wages" are usually the wages for the time you worked after the first 8 hours in a day or after the first 40 hours in a week. "Double time wages" are usually the wages for the time you worked after the first 12 hours in a day. (Note that the rules can vary depending on the type of employer, or the type of work you performed.)
Providing as much information upfront allows our office to better assist you with your claim.

Please know that many of the questions on the claim form are optional. If you do not have or know all of the information requested, approximate answers will be accepted. You can also skip to the next question and complete the form to the best of your ability.
You will be asked questions about additional parties who may be liable for part or all of your claim.
Other than your birthdate, all dates requested on the application can be approximate. Please give us your best estimate if you cannot be exact.

You can save your claim form at any time by clicking the "Save as Draft" button and resume where you left off at a later time. Your draft claim will be saved in the Draft Claims section of your dashboard. Do not use the browser back and forward arrow when completing a claim. Instead use the “Previous” and “Continue” buttons at the bottom of the page.
Once you have submitted your application, you will receive a confirmation with your case number via email.
After a claim is submitted, you can return to the online portal account to review the status of your claim as well as the date of upcoming conferences or hearings.
Welcome to the Labor Commissioner’s Online Wage Claim application.
Before filling out the wage claim, please review the tips below for guidance on completing your claim.

If someone is helping you complete this online wage claim, but is not your representative, please select "yourself." The person helping you does not need to be an attorney. They will also receive documents regarding your claim.
Did you ever have to work overtime to correct a mistake? How were you informed?
Did you ever have to work overtime to meet a deadline for delivery? How were you informed?
Were you paid at least minimum wage while waiting for work?
"I was paid" or "I was promised" field is required
Covid related means that somehow COVID-19 impacted your employment, e.g. because of the pandemic employees were laid off, business shut down, sick leave denied/unpaid, etc.

An employer is required to provide employees with cool down periods to prevent a heat illness. If they do not, your employer has to pay you a "heat recovery period wages" equal to 1 hour of your wages, for each day where they did not provide you with enough heat recovery periods.

In the event your rate of pay changed or the period of your claim was broken up by a layoff or other reason you did not work, you can click the button at the bottom of the section to enter a claim for a different rate of pay or different period of time.

Last Date cannot be smaller than Hire Date.

You do not have a right to holiday pay, unless your employer promised it.

Your hourly rate of pay can be determined by dividing a weekly salary rate by 40 hours, a biweekly salary rate by 80 hours or an annual salary rate by 2080 hours. Commission or piece rate workers may estimate their hourly rate by dividing the gross amount by the average number of hours they earned the piece rate or commission.
Total number of hours claimed for unpaid holidays

Your hourly rate of pay can be determined by dividing a weekly salary rate by 40 hours, a biweekly salary rate by 80 hours or an annual salary rate by 2080 hours. Commission or piece rate workers may estimate their hourly rate by dividing the gross amount by the average number of hours they earned the piece rate or commission.

Your hourly rate of pay can be determined by dividing a weekly salary rate by 40 hours, a biweekly salary rate by 80 hours or an annual salary rate by 2080 hours. Commission or piece rate workers may estimate their hourly rate by dividing the gross amount by the average number of hours they earned the piece rate or commission.

Severance pay is compensation and/or benefits an employer provides to an employee after employment ends. The Labor Commissioner has limited jurisdiction over claims for severance pay.

In the event your rate of pay changed or the period of your claim was broken up by a layoff or other reason you did not work, you can click the button at the bottom of the section to enter a claim for a different rate of pay or different period of time.

An employer is required to provide you with an unpaid, uninterrupted 30-minute meal break after you finish 5 hours of work, and a second 30-minute meal break after you finish 10 hours of work. If they do not, your employer has to pay you "meal period wages" equal to 1 hour of your wages, for each day where they did not provide you with enough meal breaks.
Total amount of mileage claimed for this period

Please enter a claim for one calendar year and the mileage for that year at a time. At the bottom of this screen you can click a button to enter a claim for another calendar year and mileage for as many years of mileage you are claiming. If you are unsure of the mileage rate, please use the Internal Revenue Service mileage rates shown at
Please limit your beginning and ending date for this deficiency to one calendar year.

An employer cannot lawfully withhold amounts from wages due to cash shortages, breakage, or loss of equipment. Generally, employers can only make deductions from wages when they are required by law or specifically authorized by an employee in writing.

"Regular wages" are generally the wages for the amount of time you worked in the first 8 hours of each day or first 40 hours each week.

Your hourly rate of pay can be determined by dividing a weekly salary rate by 40 hours, a biweekly salary rate by 80 hours or an annual salary rate by 2080 hours. Commission or piece rate workers may estimate their hourly rate by dividing the gross amount by the average number of hours they earned the piece rate or commission.

In the event your rate of pay changed or the period of your claim was broken up by a layoff or other reason you did not work, you can click the button at the bottom of the section to enter a claim for a different rate of pay or different period of time.

Employers are required to furnish an employee at least one-half of their scheduled shift. When an employee reports to work and is not provided half of their shift, the employer is required to make up the difference between the hours worked and one-half of the shift. E.g. employee reports for a 6-hour shift, but is sent home, the employer owes 3 hours of reporting time pay.

In the event your rate of pay changed or the period of your claim was broken up by a layoff or other reason you did not work, you can click the button at the bottom of the section to enter a claim for a different rate of pay or different period of time.
To add another reporting time claim
Enter information about the person who is representing or helping you with your claim. The person helping you does not need to be an attorney. They will also receive documents regarding your claim.

An employer is required to provide you with a paid 10-minute rest break for every 4 hours you work. If they do not, your employer may be required to pay you "rest period wages" equal to 1 hour of your wages, for each day where they did not provide you with enough rest breaks.

In the event your rate of pay changed or the period of your claim was broken up by a layoff or other reason you did not work, you can click the button at the bottom of the section to enter a claim for a different rate of pay or different period of time.
If you have been retaliated against by your employer, you may file a retaliation complaint. Please visit our Retaliation Complaint website.

It is unlawful for employers to use tips as a credit against an employee's wages. Additionally, a tip is money left by a customer for goods or services rendered. Tips belong to the employee, not the employer
Select your sick leave claim (Select one only)

Employers are required to provide an employee with information regarding paid sick leave. Both the accrual and usage of the paid sick leave must also be tracked on the itemized wage statement (check stub). Additional Covid-related sick leave may also be required. For a full discussion about sick leave requirements, please visit
To add another sick leave claim

The web link/url to your union contract

Although there is no legal requirement in California for an employer to have a paid vacation policy, if there is a policy, vacation pay adds up as it is earned and cannot be forfeited. Therefore, all accrued and unused vacation must be paid out when employment ends.

Your hourly rate of pay can be determined by dividing a weekly salary rate by 40 hours, a biweekly salary rate by 80 hours or an annual salary rate by 2080 hours. Commission or piece rate workers may estimate their hourly rate by dividing the gross amount by the average number of hours they earned the piece rate or commission.
End Date must be greater than Start Date.

In the event your rate of pay changed or the period of your claim was broken up by a layoff or other reason you did not work, you can click the button at the bottom of the section to enter a claim for a different rate of pay or different period of time.

Approximate answers are acceptable and many of the details are optional. However, providing as much information as possible allows our office to better assist you with your claim.
If there are any other claims you would like to make that are not listed here, please explain in the space provided. You have a 500 character limit
Have you received your final payment of wages including all wages owed?
Were your wages always paid on the payday established by your employer?

Your daily rate of pay can be determined by multiplying your hourly rate times the number of hours worked per day or dividing a salary rate by the number of days worked per pay period. For commision or piece rate employment, use average daily rates.

Your daily rate of pay can be determined by multiplying your hourly rate times the number of hours worked per day or dividing a salary rate by the number of days worked per pay period. For commision or piece rate employment, use average daily rates.
You indicated earlier that your final wages were not paid in a timely manner or at all. This claim has been added.

Workday: A workday is the 24 hour period used to calculate overtime and other things (like number of hours worked in a day). A standard workday is from midnight until just before midnight at the end of a calendar day.
Is the address where you worked different from the business address provided?
Add the address where you reported for work
Workweek: A workweek is the seven days used to calculate overtime and other things. A standard workweek is Sunday through Saturday.
You indicated earlier that you may not have been provided with a written statement on rate of compensation when you requested it. This deficiency has been added to your claim.

If someone is helping you complete this online wage claim, but is not your representative, please select "yourself." The person helping you does not need to be an attorney. They will also receive documents regarding your claim.
Please provide a zip code where you live.
Date your complete wages were paid to you
Did you receive itemized wage statements (pay stubs) when you received cash or check payments?

For example: laid off, dismissed, any employer initiated discharge.
I am a garment employee and was paid piece rate after December 31, 2021.

Effective January 1, 2022, employers of garment workers are required to pay their employees an hourly rate and can no longer pay piece rate wages. An employee who is paid piece rate wages may be owed compensatory damages of $200.00 for each pay period they were paid piece rate.

You may be creating a duplicate registration. If you continue, fees will be required and refunds are not permitted. Do you want to proceed?
Username is an email address.Passwords must be 8 characters or longer and include at least one uppercase, one lowercase and one symbol. Note: PASSWORD, password, and PaSsWoRd are not the same.
Passwords must be at least 8 characters long and include at least one uppercase, one lowercase, one number and one character: - ! # $ % = + _ < >
